STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 6, 2024
Stacy Houghtaling
EATON COUNTY DHHS
1050 INDEPENDENCE BLVD,
CHARLOTTE, MI, 48813-1032
Re: License #: CP230201103
Dear Stacy Houghtaling:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
8/26-8/30/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP230201103
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services

Chief Administrator: Stacy Houghtaling
Name of Agency: EATON COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 1050 INDEPENDENCE BLVD
CHARLOTTE, MI 48813-1032
Agency Telephone #: 5175430860
Original Issuance Date: 12/01/1991
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Place
children in foster home, Supervise
Independent Living

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit
and complete a written reevaluation of a foster
home.
One of Three open foster home files reviewed did not have an annual reevaluation
completed.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (4) Before completion of the written report
required by subrule (6) of this rule, an agency
shall provide the foster parent with a verbal
summary of the preliminary findings at the
conclusion of the evaluation.
One of Three files open foster home files reviewed contained documentation that a
foster family was not provided a verbal summary of preliminary findings prior to the
writing of a special evaluation report.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
2

• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (c) A physical examination for each child as
follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
• (i) A comprehensive medical
examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma
screening, within 30 calendar days
from the date the child entered into
an out-of-home placement,
regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
One of Three open files of youth in foster care placement did not contain
documentation that the youth received an initial medical exam timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 10/6/2022, CAP Approved 10/31/2022
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (e) A dental examination must be
completed within 3 months before entry into
foster care or an initial dental examination
must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care
out-of-home placement. A child entering
foster care under 1 year of age must have
an initial dental exam within 3 months of his
or her first birthday.
One of Three open files of youth in foster care placement did not contain
documentation that the youth received an initial dental exam timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 400.12413(1)(f)(i)
Interim 10/6/2022, CAP Approved 10/31/2022
3

CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
• (2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
One of Three open files of youth in independent living placement did not contain
documentation that the youth was provided IL program statement.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
• (3) An agency shall provide a youth in
independent living with a copy of the agency's
policies and procedures required by this rule.
One of Three open files of youth in independent living placement did not contain
documentation that the youth was provided IL policies and procedures.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (1) There must be a mutual agreement between
the youth and the agency specifying all the
following:
• (a) The responsibilities of the agency and
the youth.
One of Three open files of youth in independent living placement did not contain any
IL contracts between the youth and agency/worker.
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
4

no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
One of Six open files of youth (3 FC, 3 IL) did not contain all required FTMs related
to placement changes/breaks.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 7/18/2023, CAP Approved 8/4/2023
Interim 10/6/2022, CAP Approved 10/31/2022
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
5

• I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Two of Six open files of youth (3 FC, 3 IL) did not contain all required signatures on
PATPs obtained within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 7/18/2023, CAP Approved 8/4/2023
Interim 10/6/2022, CAP Approved 10/31/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was not requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was provided related to the need for the agency to complete
IL paperwork with youth transferring to their IL program even if the youth has
previously completed IL paperwork with a different agency. All IL paperwork
required per licensing rules must be specific to the agency from which the youth
is receiving IL services.
6

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The one
CAP submitted by the agency was in response to the 2023 renewal inspection
report dated 07/18/2023. That CAP was approved on 08/04/2023 and addressed
three citations, all of which were related to policy citations. The agency has
achieved and maintained compliance with that CAP in one area, medical
passports, as evidenced by the violation not being repeated during this year's
inspection. The agency did not maintain compliance related to PATP signatures
and FTMs and will require additional corrective action planning. There is an
increase in citations from three (3 policy) in 2023 to nine (7 rule & 2 policy) in
2024; however, three of the citations established this year were within one IL
youth's file. None of the violations establishes were pervasive or consistent in
nature.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment was received and reviewed during the
entrance meeting. The chief administrator identified FTMs as an area in which
there has been difficulty maintaining compliance. She reported the previous year's
CAP has been implemented well and has been successful. Multiple unplanned
placement changes has occurred and experienced difficulty locating appropriate
placement for youths with high needs.
Financial Overview
Not Applicable.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed did not report any concerns. They all state they receive
regular and frequent supervision. They state supervision has increased their
support and assistance over the past year. They all also feel spreadsheets and
meeting requirements implemented after the last CAP have been helpful.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment to provide foster
care, licensing, and independent living service delivery. CHRI is stored in a locked
cabinet and cross shredding is available on-site.
7

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
September 6, 2024
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 6, 2024
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
8
